newsitem.title: COLOMBIA: "No computers, please!" prize-winning writer says.
newsitem.headline: "No computers, please!" prize-winning writer says.

text.p: Colombian poet and novelist Alvaro Mutis, who won Spain's top literary prize on Friday, is a self-described ignoramus who still writes on an ageing typewriter and shuns computers.
"I'm not interested in them at all. I don't want to know anything about computers or the Internet. I'm an integral ignoramus," Mutis said.

Mutis, born in Bogota in 1923, was speaking in a telephone interview with Colombia's Caracol radio network from his home in Mexico City. He said he was woken up before dawn by a caller anxious to tell him he had just won Spain's prestigious Principe de Asturias literary award.
"I wasn't expecting the prize but I appreciate it immensely," he said.

Mutis is a contemporary and friend of fellow Colombian exile and Nobel Prize-winner Gabriel Garcia Marquez, who has said he began working on a computer several years ago and finds that it facilitates the writing process immensely.
Mutis, whose work is little known in English, said he would stick with the typewriter on which he has been writing for at least 25 years.
But in a small concession to technology, he acknowledged that the typewriter is electric, not manual.
